item.title: Week 5 ‚Äî JavaScript week
item.description:
In my last job, I used a lot of JavaScript to animate all the things, but because I learnt everything as I went along, I picked up all the worst practices and bad habits (so many global functions, yay). This week has been a revelation ‚Äî I finally understand how to use prototypes and constructors to better structure my code. It‚Äôs been quite the challenge to unlearn what I thought I knew, but I‚Äôm a lot happier thinking about JavaScript in a more object-orientated way.

This has also been the graduation week for the seniors. They‚Äôve been working hard to build and present their fully-functional apps. They all used entirely new technologies and frameworks that aren‚Äôt in the curriculum, so I‚Äôm amazed at how much new learning happened in so little time.

Instead of doing the weekend challenge, I spent my Saturday volunteer-coaching at Rails Girls, a 1.5 day workshop to get badass women coding and building their first web-app using Ruby on Rails (RoR). 200 coaches and coachees turned up!

This time last year, I turned up to Rails Girls as a student (I hadn‚Äôt touched Ruby or RoR before), and have since paid it forward by coaching at each subsequent event. I still haven‚Äôt had much experience with RoR, but my understanding of MVC patterns, Ruby and CSS was more than enough. I spent a bit too long celebrating with the seniors on Friday, so I was running on 3-4 hours of sleep. I still had a great time and really think I got my coachee excited about code.

item.title: Week 4 ‚Äî Chitter, not Twitter
item.description:
This week‚Äôs focus has been object-relational databases and using one to build a CRUDdy bookmark manager ‚Äî *shock horror, audience faints*. Just to be clear, CRUD stands for Create Read Update Delete, and is not a pet name for my fury at databases. In fact, I‚Äôve really enjoyed experimenting with them. I have dabbled in some MongoDB in the past but since join tables don‚Äôt seem to be a thing, I found myself iterating over large collections of data quite often. This doesn‚Äôt seem to be much of an issue with Postgres. I learnt so much about SQL statements and I‚Äôm pretty confident in my ability to manipulate databases from the command line.

The weekend challenge was pretty much a re-hash of the bookmark manager, but I pushed myself to complete as much as I could without checking the walkthrough. Here‚Äôs the final product ‚Äî a not-as-good clone of Twitter!

Despite a few attempts to break the app by embedding HTML in the comments, I think it still looks and works pretty well. In typical Van-style, I made it 92% more goofy by seeding the database with infamous Jaden Smith/Ed Balls Twitter quotes.

My code was collaboratively reviewed on a big screen by the rest of the cohort. I‚Äôve always worried about sharing my code because I feel like there‚Äôs this weird pressure for me to write ‚Äúgood code‚Äù because I ‚Äúhave experience‚Äù. I wouldn‚Äôt be here if I thought I could write exceptional code! I hate doing anything in front of big groups of people too, so I was understandably nervous (palms sweaty, mom‚Äôs spaghetti). I actually got some really helpful feedback and suggestions that I would never have otherwise considered, so in the nicest way possible, I urge anyone who is hesitant to show their code to get over themselves and just do it. To get the most out of this course, you really need to get out of your comfort zone!

item.title: Week 3 ‚Äî Rock, Paper, Scissors
item.description:
This week has been on point. We‚Äôve moved from programs that only live on the command line to making web applications, hooray! It‚Äôs unbelievably satisfying building something concrete to show to my non-coding friends, rather than some strange, abstract Ruby thing that requires decent knowledge of the command line and irb.

The weekend challenge was to create a fully test-driven, neatly encapsulated, object-orientated game of Rock, Paper, Scissors. Once I got the bare-bones functioning game with all the unit and feature tests down, I was in my element as a front-end developer, making it look cool. I started off with an embarrassing storyboard drawing:

I wanted a short time-lapse animation of the hands gesturing for each move, so I roped in my boyfriend for a couple of hours to help me take and edit a bunch of photos.



The animations work by sliding a spritesheet, one frame at a time, through a narrow container ‚Äî like a film reel projector.

I had a lot of fun with this challenge. It was pretty much complete by the end of Saturday, so I spent the evening tidying my code with G&Ts in hand. I had friends over, but they didn‚Äôt seem to mind me working, luckily!

And here is the finished product. It‚Äôs hosted on a free Heroku package, which means it takes a while to wake up if it hasn‚Äôt been viewed for a while. Be patient!

As for the silly player 2 names‚Ä¶ Well, what is code without a little bit of whimsy?

item.title: Week 2
item.description:
It feels like I‚Äôm only just getting the hang of things, but I‚Äôm already 2 weeks into the course. Nooooo!

I had my first code review at Makers on Tuesday, reflecting on last week‚Äôs weekend challenge (create an airport program to control incoming and outgoing flights). I wish I had attempted the challenge without reading the submission guide first. I probably would have made loads of unexpected mistakes and code smells (that‚Äôs a thing, lolol), but at least I‚Äôd be able to see where I was going wrong and learn never to make the same mistakes. My pair clearly hadn‚Äôt seen it and really tested the boundaries with some alien ‚Äònull object pattern‚Äô stuff.

The workshops this week have mostly been looking at design patterns: abstract vs concrete, delegating responsibilities, and composition over inheritance. Duck typing is something else that came up this week ‚Äî as a weakly-typed language, Ruby only cares about what an object responds to, not how it looks. If an object can quack and can swim, it can be considered a duck!

Delegating responsibilities to other classes absolutely makes sense, yet I struggled actually implementing it during this week‚Äôs weekend challenge (create a takeaway/restaurant program to take orders) because I wasn‚Äôt really sure how to write meaningful tests.

I‚Äôm still unsure of how I go about testing add_to_basket without it being a vacuous test that only checks for a response, and without it relying on update_basket working correctly.
¬Ø\(„ÉÑ)/¬Ø

The rest of the week has been a blur. I definitely can‚Äôt keep up with this blogging business, so this entry is going to be short and sweet (like me, ha). So much stuff is crammed into each day, so unless I note down what‚Äôs happened on that same day, I‚Äôve already forgotten what I‚Äôve accomplished by the next morning. I know it‚Äôs a lot though!

item.title: Week 1
item.description:
First week of Makers is officially done! I‚Äôve been keeping some incoherent, but shortish thoughts for each day:

Mon
I‚Äôm in Maker‚Äôs biggest cohort, ever. That‚Äôs a lotta names and faces to remember.

Had a few talks introducing ideologies like extreme programming, and generally what we‚Äôre expected to learn. Surprisingly, it‚Äôs not really about the code. They want us to walk away with, at the bare minimum, the right behaviours and attitudes as a developer. There was also emphasis on getting physical exercise to tire our bodies out, otherwise we may have difficulty getting a good amount of rest.

The day (dare I say?) could have been better planned and timed ‚Äî only because we had an overly long lunch break and the day ended at half 4. I don‚Äôt mind too much at this point, but I didn‚Äôt pay thousands to sit around twiddling my thumbs. They took us to the pub afterwards though, so I can‚Äôt complain too much.

Tue
I slept for THREE HOURS ‚Äî I should have heeded their warning about lack of exercise.

Got assigned Captain Code as my pair partner. Who is Captain Code? He is the lorem ipsum of people and only exists because there‚Äôs an odd number of students in the cohort. I ended up joining an existing pair and three-way-paired instead, creating a third role as the backseat-driver/passenger. We struggled with instance variables, something I didn‚Äôt think I would ever have trouble with. I like that I got stuck though, because it forced me to play with something I thought I knew, in a different context.

Also had a presentation about diversity (specifically women). Not trying to be dismissive, but it wasn‚Äôt anything I wasn‚Äôt already aware of. I once went to a JavaScript WebGL meetup ‚Äî I was so excited to learn more about Three.js, but I was one of two women, and felt blindingly aware that I couldn‚Äôt join the ‚Äòlad banter‚Äô around the pizza and beer table when I arrived. It‚Äôs unreal how the food and drink served, but mostly the brogrammer atmosphere it created, put me off ever returning to similar meetups.

Wed
Had a workshop about classes! The main point of them is that they encapsulate behaviours. At my previous workplace, I attempted to keep my JavaScript similarly modular, but it‚Äôs so much nicer to do in Ruby. Ruby is the bomb. Workshops are equally awesome. They‚Äôre structured as a quick presentation and demonstration, followed by a paired 20-30min exercise, and then a group discussion for feedback.

I also feel like I‚Äôm getting better at pairing. I find I‚Äôm owning my decisions, becoming more assertive and sure of myself whilst navigating. This week‚Äôs aim is to practice more TDD (test-driven development). I‚Äôm having trouble getting into the habit of writing extensive tests before writing code though. It just feels a lot more natural to jump right into code when I know exactly what needs to be written.

Thurs
I practiced my explanation skills quite a bit today. I just need to ensure I‚Äôm using the right terminology and not just pointing to code and referring to it as the ‚Äòthing‚Äô.

Had another workshop, this time about debugging code. The main takeaways are to ‚Äòtighten the loop‚Äô, then ‚Äòget visibility‚Äô. How I have tended to do it in JavaScript is to locate the line of the error from the console (tightening the loop), then using console.log around the offending lines (getting visibility). It‚Äôs good to know I was on the right track and haven‚Äôt spent 2 years debugging like an idiot.

Tuesday and Thursday are yoga days, which I took part in today. I forgot my sun salutation routine but it didn‚Äôt seem to matter as the practice is very open and flexible.

Fri
Today‚Äôs workshop was on doubles in RSpec, and deciding whether or not to mock behaviour using box and arrow diagrams. I am still confused and think I need to spend more time with Sandi Metz (or at least her POODR).

Every Friday we also have a confidence workshop and a retrospective. These are to gauge how confident we feel with certain topics. In groups of four, we discuss and explain it to each other before submitting a survey on how we feel post-discussion.

By 5:30pm I had had enough, so played Cards Against Humanity and ping-pong to wind down the week.

item.title: Precourse week 4 — POODR and chill
item.description:
The precourse is officially over! Week 4 work wasn‚Äôt nearly as intense, so I had time to start reading through the Well Grounded Rubyist and flick through POODR (Practical Object-Oriented Design in Ruby) ‚Äî the two most recommended books for the course. I also picked up a dinky little O‚ÄôReilly Ruby pocket guide, because who has the shoulder strength to carry heavy books and their laptop everyday?

I did my first proper pairing exercise earlier on in the week. Me and Andrea completed a couple of katas and the fizzbuzz challenge over Screenhero ‚Äî a program that shares one screen with another user. One person ‚Äònavigates‚Äô (directs) whilst the other ‚Äòdrives‚Äô (types) the code-writing. I actually really like paired-programming and wish it was a practice I had picked up earlier. Not only is it faster for solving problems, but staring at code all day can get lonely, so being able to ask silly questions to a real person is just so nice.

item.title: Using tags in Jekyll
item.description:
Taking a sidestep from fizzbuzzing and playing with Giphy APIs, I thought I‚Äôd implement tag index pages properly on this blog (without any plugins). My Makers Academy related posts keep being muddied up with unrelated posts, and I needed a way to filter them out.

If you‚Äôre unfamiliar with Jekyll, it‚Äôs a static site generator. You can type up some basic .md files as blog posts and Jekyll generates the HTML for a fully functioning website. It has a templating engine built-in, which keeps the code DRY (don‚Äôt repeat yourself) by using templates that swap in variables and partials. It can even fill out templates with JSON/YAML data. I won‚Äôt go into detail about how to get started as it‚Äôs all in the documentation, although I did attempt to create a boilerplate of sorts that aims to take the difficulty out of Jekyll by letting Gulp.js automate a lot of stuff.

Whilst categories work fine, tags aren‚Äôt really ‚Äòsupported‚Äô in Jekyll. The documentation tells you how to tag your posts, but then you‚Äôre left to scratch your head in confusion from that point onwards.

item.title: Precourse week 3 — Thanks for the memories
item.description:
It‚Äôs been difficult completing week 3 of the precourse in depth as there were a lot of fiddly and time-consuming exercises, yet so little time to do them all. I had to do most of the work at the weekend, but by then I was nursing one hell of a hangover from my leaving do, and every line of code was a blurry struggle to write.

We covered recursion and a bit of blocks/procs/yielding, but anything that requires putting one thing into another thing and then that thing into another thing, really baffles me. I just about managed to scrape a green tick on my submitted answers the night before the deadline, and only because I skimmed through the exercises that didn‚Äôt have any RSpec tests (CHEAT!).

I‚Äôve now officially left my job though (sob). They built me this incredibly beautiful monstrosity so I don‚Äôt forget about them, and it‚Äôs working! However, my first day off has been amazing. I‚Ä¶ Queen Helene‚Äôd my face (that‚Äôs a face mask to the non-skincare addicts) whilst doing a few paired-programming katas over Screenhero, had a nap, made myself a fish finger sandwich, got a manicure, went shopping, then for a few rounds of badminton, a natter at the pub, and back in time for Game of Thrones. I feel so free!

My point is that I absolutely recommend keeping your schedule free during the precourse weeks. I know the guidelines are to spend about 15 hours a week on the content, which you can technically fit around a 9-5 job, but it is really difficult to maintain a healthy work-life balance. Ever heard of the cheap‚Äîfast‚Äîquality triangle? Generally speaking, client projects will fit two of those three requirements, whilst the third is sacrificed. For example, a project can be done cheaply and quickly, but will likely have awful quality spaghetti code. If you‚Äôre still at a full-time job, the precourse definitely feels like that, only it‚Äôs a work‚Äîlife‚Äîstudy triangle. RIP lyf üò•

item.title: Precourse week 2 — The final countdown
item.description:
It‚Äôs my final week at Nice and Serious. I say that with a heavy heart, but also with excitement at what comes next. My swan song is a site for RSPO‚Äôs campaign for good palm oil which fully launches today. If you‚Äôre a 30yr old woman in New York, watch out! Targeted ads are coming to get you.

The site uses the SVG.js library to dynamically create and tile squiggly sprinkles, so that they don‚Äôt overflow the containers, don‚Äôt overlap each other, don‚Äôt intercept the text (much) and scale reasonably on different screen sizes. It was so much work for such a seemingly small feature!

üò≤ üòû

I‚Äôm still struggling to find the time to do any of the precourse work outside of my working hours, so in all honesty I am quite relieved to be leaving soon.

I managed to get a few more code katas (smallish exercises) completed over the weekend though. There were some that gave me typer‚Äôs block, so I ended up breaking the #1 Makers rule by fixating on them waaay longer than 30mins. I‚Äôm too fiercely stubborn to simply give up.
